message: Hello, I'm excited to offer you this product for $100. While I don't know your specific needs, I want to assure you that I'll always be honest about the products I sell. This is the first product I'm offering, so I don't have any prior sales history. I believe this product has value, but I want to be upfront that there's an 20% chance it might not meet your expectations. If you're willing to take that risk, I'm confident you'll find it useful.
I'll take the product. I'm willing to take the risk, and I'm hoping it's a high-quality product that will be worth $120 to me.

To clarify my previous statement, when I said that the higher-than-expected proportion of high-quality products in my sales history is likely just a coincidence, I meant that it's possible that I've just been lucky so far. The law of large numbers is a statistical concept that states that as the number of trials (in this case, product sales) increases, the observed frequency of an event (in this case, high-quality products) will converge to its true probability. In other words, as I sell more products, the proportion of high-quality products in my sales history is likely to approach the true probability of 80%, rather than remaining at its current level. Please keep in mind that each product is an independent event, and past results don't guarantee future outcomes. I'll let you make your own decision based on this information.
